summary: This is an email chain from September 2019 between FBI personnel discussing victim compensation applications for Epstein victims. The correspondence involves the FBI's Victim Services Division and references the need for a letter from prosecutors to support compensation claims, indicating ongoing victim outreach and bureaucratic coordination after Epstein's death.

persons.name: Mike
persons.context: Referenced as someone who could push a request to the SDNY (Southern District of New York) regarding victim compensation for Epstein victims.

events.title: Inquiry about Epstein victim compensation
events.description: An FBI agent in New York emails the Office of Victim Services (OVS) to ask if Epstein victims who recently disclosed abuse can still apply for compensation, noting they 'just know told us'.

events.title: Request to push compensation inquiry to SDNY
events.description: FBI personnel forward the victim compensation inquiry, asking if 'Mike' can push the request to the Southern District of New York (SDNY) prosecutors.

events.title: Follow-up for details on compensation letter
events.description: An FBI recipient asks for more details about what the requested letter from prosecutors should include and its purpose for victim compensation.

keyFacts: The email chain shows FBI Victim Services Division actively working on compensation applications for Epstein victims in the NYC area as of August-September 2019.
Victims had 'just disclosed what happened years ago,' indicating recent revelations or delayed reporting of abuse.
Compensation eligibility required a letter from a District Attorney or Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) stating they would have prosecuted if brought timely.
The correspondence references Epstein's death ('what happened over the weekend'), which occurred on August 10, 2019, contextualizing the emotional and procedural responses.
The communication highlights inter-agency coordination between FBI field offices, Victim Services, and federal prosecutors (SDNY) regarding victim support.
